verses.text: The wisdom of the humble will lift his head high, and set him among the great.
verses.comment: This verse echoes the theme that humility brings exaltation, later reaffirmed by Jesus (Luke 14:11). God values humility and raises up the lowly—a thread seen throughout salvation history.
verses.sectionHeader: The Wisdom of the Humble and the Mystery of Fortune

verses.text: Do not praise a man for his looks, nor despise anyone because of his appearance.
verses.comment: God looks at the heart (1 Sam. 16:7). Outward status means little before God, a recurring biblical principle.

verses.text: The bee is small among the flying creatures, yet her produce is of the sweetest.
verses.comment: God often uses the small and overlooked (1 Cor. 1:27-29). Spiritual fruit may come from humble origins.

verses.text: Do not boast about your fine clothes or exalt yourself in the day of honor; for the works of the Lord are marvelous, and his deeds are hidden from mankind.
verses.comment: True honor comes from God, often quietly and unexpectedly. Human recognition is fleeting.

verses.text: Many kings have sat on the ground, while someone the world considers insignificant has worn a crown.
verses.comment: God reverses worldly expectations. He exalts the humble and brings down the proud—Mary will echo this in the Magnificat (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: Many rulers have been utterly disgraced, and the renowned handed over to others.
verses.comment: God's providence can overturn human plans and prestige, a warning against pride.

verses.text: Do not blame before you have examined; understand first, then rebuke.
verses.comment: Judgment must be just and informed (Matthew 7:1). This principle lays the groundwork for fairness in both human and heavenly communities.
verses.sectionHeader: Judging Others and Moderation in Pursuits

verses.text: Do not answer before you have listened, and do not interrupt someone in the middle of their words.
verses.comment: Patience in judgment reflects God’s own perfect discernment.

verses.text: Do not argue about a matter that does not concern you, and do not sit with sinners when they judge a case.
verses.comment: This warns against gossip and meddling, guarding community charity and unity.

verses.text: My son, do not take on too many pursuits; if you multiply tasks, you will not be guiltless. If you pursue, you will not overtake; if you flee, you will not escape.
verses.comment: An admonition for moderation and trust in God’s providence—our efforts alone do not guarantee success.

verses.text: There are those who work and struggle and hurry, but are so much the more in want.
verses.comment: This verse critiques a purely materialistic, frantic pursuit of gain, echoing themes from Ecclesiastes (Eccl 2:22-23), reminding readers that relentless toil can still end in want if not blessed by God.

verses.text: There are others who are slow and need help, who lack strength and abound in poverty; but the eyes of the Lord look kindly upon them; he lifts them out of their lowly condition
verses.comment: Contrasting with the previous verse, it describes the vulnerable who, despite outward lack, are recipients of God's providential care—a reversal motif found also in the Psalms (Ps 113:7-8).

verses.text: and raises up their heads to the amazement of the many.
verses.comment: God’s favor can unexpectedly exalt the humble, confounding social expectations, reflecting the biblical theme that God ‘raises the lowly’ (Lk 1:52).

verses.text: Good and evil, life and death, poverty and riches—they come from the Lord.
verses.comment: God is sovereign over all outcomes (Isa. 45:7). This is a call to trust in His providence, regardless of circumstance.
verses.sectionHeader: The Providence of God in Wealth and Adversity

verses.text: Wisdom and understanding and knowledge of the law are from the Lord; love and the way of good works are from him.
verses.comment: All true wisdom, understanding, and the capacity for love and moral action originate with God, reinforcing the biblical doctrine of divine source (Prov 2:6; Jas 1:17).

verses.text: Error and darkness were created with sinners; and evil will grow old with those who take pride in evil.
verses.comment: This verse teaches that sin and spiritual darkness are consequences of rejecting God, warning that pride in evil perpetuates separation from divine light (Jn 3:19-20).

verses.text: The Lord's gift endures with the godly; His approval will lead them to prosperity forever.
verses.comment: Spiritual blessings are lasting. This verse hints at perseverance and faithfulness being rewarded eternally.

verses.text: One becomes rich through diligence and self-denial, and the reward allotted to him is this:
verses.comment: Wealth acquired through diligence and self-restraint is not condemned, but presented as a possible divine reward, resonating with traditional wisdom (Prov 10:4), though ultimate security still depends on God.

verses.text: He says, 'I have found rest, now I will enjoy my wealth.' But he does not realize how soon he will leave it all to others and die.
verses.comment: Life is uncertain; only treasures laid up in God endure (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Stay faithful to your covenant and grow old in your work.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and perseverance in one's calling is pleasing to God. Work and covenant loyalty are united, with spiritual overtones reminiscent of the Church’s view of vocation.

verses.text: Do not marvel at the works of sinners; trust in the Lord and remain steadfast in your labor, for it is easy in God's sight to make a poor man rich, swiftly and suddenly.
verses.comment: Trust in God’s timing. Outward success of the wicked is not the final word.

verses.text: The blessing of the Lord is the reward of the godly, and He makes their plans succeed.
verses.comment: Success is possible only through God’s blessing—a call to commit one’s works to Him.

verses.text: Do not say, 'What do I need? What good will come to me in the future?'
verses.comment: This anticipates Jesus’ teaching on trusting God for tomorrow (Matt. 6:34). Humility recognizes our dependence.
verses.sectionHeader: The Uncertainty of Happiness and the End of Life

verses.text: Do not say, “I have enough, and what harm can come to me now?”
verses.comment: A warning against presumption and complacency, paralleling Jesus' parable of the rich fool (Lk 12:19-20); prosperity can breed false security apart from God.

verses.text: In the day of prosperity, adversity is forgotten, and in the day of adversity, prosperity is not remembered.
verses.comment: This reflection on the fickleness of memory in different life seasons highlights human tendency to lose perspective, comparable to Job’s oscillation between blessing and suffering (Job 29-30).

verses.text: It is easy for the Lord, on the day of death, to repay a man according to his deeds.
verses.comment: This alludes to judgment after death. The concept of being repaid for deeds is taught also by Jesus and the apostles.

verses.text: An hour’s misery makes one forget past delights, and at the close of one’s life one’s deeds are revealed.
verses.comment: The brevity and power of suffering can eclipse a lifetime of pleasure, emphasizing the ultimate revelation of one’s deeds at life’s end (cf. Eccl 7:8; Rom 2:6).

verses.text: Do not call any man happy before his death; for by how he ends will a man be known.
verses.comment: Perseverance to the end is key (2 Tim. 4:7). The importance of finishing the race well is a deeply biblical theme.

verses.text: Do not bring everyone into your house, for deceitful men have many tricks.
verses.comment: A practical warning regarding discernment in relationships—protects community purity.

verses.text: Like a decoy partridge in a cage, so is the mind of the proud, and like spies they observe your weakness;
verses.comment: The image of traps and snares is common in the Psalms; vigilance is required.

verses.text: Even good things for you may turn to evil, and with glee they will twist your best actions into accusations.
verses.comment: Even good works can be slandered, as seen with the persecution of the righteous—an experience Christ warns his followers about (Matt. 5:11).

verses.text: From a spark of evil a great fire arises; a sinner waits to spill blood.
verses.comment: Small evils can grow rapidly—James compares the tongue to a fire, underlining the need for spiritual discipline.

verses.text: Take care against troublemakers, for they plot evil and may bring lasting dishonor upon you.
verses.comment: Association with evildoers endangers not only reputation but one’s soul—guard against influences that threaten your walk with God.

verses.text: If you bring a stranger into your house, he may stir up trouble and estrange you from those closest to you.
verses.comment: Hospitality is good, but discernment is needed. The Christian community requires wise stewardship of relationships for unity and peace.
